awd_titl_txt: In Situ Formation of Short Period Terrestrial Planets
awd_abstract_narration:
A team of scientists at the University of Washington will perform computer simulations of the formation of rocky planets around other stars. The idea that rocky planets in our own Solar System were formed from much smaller bodies explains many features of the Solar System.  They will investigate whether this same idea can successfully explain the formation of the planetary systems found around other stars. Their results will address whether our own Solar System is an outlier in how it formed. The study will focus on the systems of planets very close to low mass stars, which are the most common of type of planetary system discovered. This program will allow university students to gain experience in high performance computing and the handling of “big data”. Some of the work will be done in small projects for undergraduate students participating in the University of Washington's Pre-Major in Astronomy Program (PreMAP). PreMAP provides under-represented students in STEM with research opportunities in astronomy.

To date, planetary Systems with Tightly-packed Inner Planets (STIPs) are the most statistically well-represented type of exoplanetary system, making them an excellent testbed for planet formation theories. However, planet formation models designed to reproduce the structure of our own Solar System typically fail to explain the seemingly exotic population of STIPs. A key component of the standard model of terrestrial planet formation is the growth from approximately kilometer size bodies to full sized planets, a regime where the physics is dominated by gravitational interactions and collisions between bodies. The team will use a recently enhanced, highly scalable particle code to follow the evolution of planetesimals on short period orbits as they interact gravitationally and collide. The results from these simulations will then be passed to a symplectic particle code to follow the late stages of planet formation for many millions of dynamical times. Using planetesimal compositions motivated by protoplanetary disk chemistry models, compositions of the terrestrial planets that result will be predicted, allowing future observations observations of the atmospheric composition of STIPs with James Webb Space Telescope to validate or falsify the possibility of in situ formation. Additionally, the gravitational influence of an outer giant companion during the accretion process will be considered, which may provide ways to infer the presence of an undetected giant companion from the orbital and compositional properties of the terrestrial planets

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The standard model for the formation of the terrestrial planets in our
Solar System includes a stage where the material that becomes
incorporated into the planets are distributed in a disk around the Sun
in the form of trillions of roughly kilometer sized rocky bodies
(planetesimals).  Through mutual collisions over hundreds of millions
of years these planetesimals eventually merge together to build up the
few planets that we see today.  Given that the architecture of
exoplanetary systems can be quite different than our own, it is
unclear whether this paradigm can be used to explain the formation of
other planetary systems.  In particular, many exoplanetary systems are
composed of a number of terrestrial-sized planets very close to their
parent stars, referred to as Systems of Tightly-packed Inner Planets
(STIPs).  This project explored the consequences of the planetesimal
planet formation model for these systems.

One of the advantages of the standard terrestrial planet formation
model is the simplicity of the physics: Newtonian gravity is the only
force involved and all collisions between bodies result in their
merger into a larger body.  However proper modeling of theses systems
is extremely computationally intensive since millions of bodies need
to be followed over millions of years while resolving two body
interaction requires timescales of less than one hour.  This project
spent considerable effort to efficiently perform this modeling on
computing clusters and on graphics processing units (GPUs) to follow,
for the first time, the planetesimal merging process all the way
through to producing the final planets.

The results of these computations demonstrate that the planetesimal
model is indeed viable for explaining the formation of STIPs, although
with some subtle differences from the formation of the Solar System
terrestrial planets.  Compared to models of terrestrial planet
formation, a larger fraction of the planetesimals end up being
incorporated into the forming planets, leaving very few small bodies
remaining.  Furthermore, the innermost planets that form are likely to
experience collisions with each other, such that the collisions are of
sufficient energy to complete disrupt the planets.  Hence the models
predict a dearth of planets very close to their parent stars, which is
consistent with results from observational surveys of planetary
systems.  This is another piece of evidence to suggest
that the planetesimal formation model may be the primary pathway to
build these compact multi-planet systems.

Understanding origins questions like the formation of terrestrial-sized
planets is a compelling research topic for early undergraduate science
majors or premajors.  This project has attracted a few students from
this population at the University of Washington and engaged them in
analyzing the results of our simulations and improving our modeling of
collisions between planetesimals.  At least one of these students
chose to continue as an Astronomy Major.
